definitions.definition: to slide a short distance by accident so that you fall or nearly fall

examples.text: She slipped and landed flat on her back.
As I ran up the stairs, my foot slipped and I fell.
She got on her feet and ran towards the door, slipping and sliding.
He slipped on a bar of soap in the shower room.
She slipped over on the ice and broke her leg.

definitions.definition: to slide out of position or out of your hand

examples.text: My hand slipped as I was slicing the bread and I cut myself.
His hat had slipped over one eye.
The fish slipped out of my hand.
The child slipped from his grasp and ran off.
She was careful not to let her control slip.

definitions.definition: to go somewhere quickly and quietly, especially without being noticed

examples.text: She slipped out of the house before the others were awake.
I slipped away before the end of the performance.
The ship slipped into the harbour at night.
A guard was posted at the door, in case anyone tried to slip in.
She knew that time was slipping away.

definitions.definition: to put something somewhere quickly, quietly or secretly
definitions.sensetop: slip something + adv./prep.slip something to somebodyslip somebody something

examples.text: Anna slipped her hand into his.
He slipped the letter back into its envelope.
He beat three defenders before slipping the ball past the goalkeeper.
She slipped her head around the door.
I managed to slip a few jokes into my speech.
I managed to slip in a few jokes.
I slipped the ring onto my finger.
They'd slipped some money to the guards.
They'd slipped the guards some money.

definitions.definition: to fall to a lower level; to become worse

examples.text: Standards have slipped in the last few years.
His popularity has slipped recently.
The director never lets the tension slip.
That's three times she's beaten me—I **must be slipping**!
A defeat would see them slip down the rankings.
At that time the Conservatives were slipping in the polls.
Pre-tax profits slipped from $3.9 million to $3.7 million,.

definitions.definition: to pass into a particular state or situation, especially a difficult or unpleasant one

examples.text: He began to **slip into** debt.
The patient had **slipped into** a coma.
We seem to have slipped behind schedule.

definitions.definition: to put clothes on or to take them off quickly and easily

examples.text: to **slip into/out of a dress**
to **slip your shoes on/off**
He slipped a coat over his sweatshirt.

definitions.definition: to get free; to make something/somebody/yourself free from something

examples.text: The ship had slipped its moorings in the night.
The dog slipped its collar.
The animal had **slipped free** and escaped.

definitions.definition: to give somebody information that is supposed to be secret

examples.text: I happened to **let it slip** that he had given me £1 000 for the car.
She tried not to let slip what she knew.

definitions.definition: to miss or fail to use an opportunity

examples.text: Don't let the chance to work abroad slip through your fingers.
She said nothing in case her temper slipped out of gear.

definitions.definition: to be easy to say or pronounce

examples.text: It's not a name that exactly trips off the tongue, is it?

definitions.definition: if something slips your mind, you forget it or forget to do it

examples.text: I’m sorry I didn’t tell you. It completely slipped my mind.

definitions.definition: to be easy to say or pronounce

examples.text: It's not a name that exactly slips off the tongue, is it?

definitions.definition: when somebody/something slips through the net, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them

examples.text: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the net.

wordOrigin: verb Middle English (in the sense ‘move quickly and softly’): probably from Middle Low German slippen (verb); compare with slippery.
